title-group.article-title: Free vibration of thick laminated cylindrical shells with different boundary conditions using general differential quadrature

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Mississippi State University, USA
2School of Engineering and Technology, Central Michigan University, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ebrahim Asadi, Department of Mechanical Engineering. Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, USA Email: easadi8@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Equations of motion with required boundary conditions for deep and thick cylindrical composite shells are shown using two First-order Shear Deformation Theories. The difference between them is the inclusion of the effects of curvature in the evaluation of stiffness parameters. Equations of motion with stress resultants lead to a system of fifteen first-order differential equations for dynamics of cylindrical shells. These equations are solved numerically using the General Differential Quadrature method for free vibration of isotropic, cross-ply, angle-ply and general lay-up cylindrical shells with six types of different boundary conditions using the aforementioned theories. The first five frequency parameters and mode shapes which are obtained from both theories are compared with the available results in the literature and those obtained using a three-dimensional finite element analysis to test the accuracy of the shell theories presented here.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The light weight and high stiffness of structures made of laminated composite materials have provided excellent new opportunities in the design of engineering structures such as automotive, aerospace and submarine ones. The simplicity of shell and plate theories and the complexity of composite structures making them hard to analyze by three dimensional (3D) elasticity methods have led to the development of different shell and plate theories. In the development of plate theories, the thickness ratio is the main issue in categorizing different plate theories which are mainly classified intoClassical Theories, First-order Shear Deformation Theories (FSDTs) and Higher-order Shear Deformation Theories (HSDTs). Besides the effect of the thickness of shells, the effects of the depth ratio of shells should beincluded in the development of shell theories. Some researchers included the effects of depth ratio in the development of shell theories (Qatu, 1995, 1999; Asadi and Qatu, 2012; Asadi et al., 2012; Khdeir, 2011; Yaghoubshahi et al., 2011). However, in spite of the effects of the thickness ratio, the effects of depth ratio need to be examined in the development of different shell theories.

Appearance of the term (1 + z/R) in both the strain displacement and stress resultant equations in the derivation of the basic equation of shells makes it difficult to include the effects of depth ratio in shell theories. The term was neglected by the first analysts of composite thin shells (e.g. Ambartsumian, 1962) which is understandable for thin shells. In addition to the inclusion of this term, both shear deformation and rotary inertia should be included for composite thick shells. Early shear deformation shell theories included both shear deformation and rotary inertia rotary but failed to include the z/R terms (Rath and Das, 1973; Reddy, 1984). These will be referred to as simply the First-order Shear Deformation Theory (FSDT). Interestingly, some researchers developed higher order theories while still neglecting the term, e.g. (Reddy and Liu, 1985; Librescu et al., 1989a, b). Qatu (1995, 1999) presented equations where the term is considered in the shell equations for composite deep thick shells. His equations will be referred to as the First-order Shear Deformation Shell Theory by Qatu (FSDTQ). Asadi et al. (2012) used FSDTQ to find the exact static and free vibration solution of isotropic and composite deep and thick shells with fully simply supported boundary conditions. They showed that using of FSDTQ instead of FSDT significantly improves the results as compared to 3D results. However, the effect of using FSDTQ on shells with different boundary conditions and general lay-ups of laminates needs to be examined. Much of the literature on shell analysis is reviewed recently showing that inaccurate equations are still used in a significant portion of shells works (Carrera, 2002, 2003; Carrera et al., 2011; Qatu et al., 2010; 2012).

Equations of motion with required boundary conditions for a deep and thick cylindrical composite shell are obtained using FSDTQ. It is shown that FSDT is a simplification from FSDTQ where the effects of the depth in the shell analysis are neglected. The equations of motion are put together with the equations of stress resultants to arrive at a system of fifteen first-order differential equations. General Differential Quadrature (GDQ) method is employed to solve this system of first-order differential equations to find the shell natural frequencies and mode shapes. Isotropic, cross-ply, angle-ply and general lay-up cylindrical shells with sixtypes of different boundary conditions which are combinations of simply supported, clamped, and free boundary conditions are examined using both FSDTQ and FSDT. Moreover, the first five natural frequency parameters and relevant mode shapes for those shells are obtained and compared with those of a converged 3D finite element analysis done by ANSYS®. Also, errors of FSDTQ and FSDT results (when comparing them to those of the 3D results) are obtained and discussed.

sec.title: 2. Formulation
sec.p:
A cylindrical shell with in-plane axis x in the direction of the axis of shell, circumferential in-plane axis β, normal to the middle-plane axis z and radius R, Figure 1, is considered. The Hamilton’s principle for a body with surface S and volume V between two arbitrary time intervals t0 and t1 requires that (1)∫t0t1{∫V[σxδɛx+σβδɛβ+σzδɛz+σxβδγxβ+σxzδγxz +σβzδγβz-ρ(u·δu·+v·δv·+w·δw·)]dV -∫SδWextdS}dt=0, where σ… and ɛ…, respectively, are stress and strain components, ρ is the mass density, and δWext is the external work. Employing the first-order shear deformation model, the displacement components is approximated as (2)u(x,β,z,t)=u0(x,β,t)+zψx(x,β,t),v(x,β,z,t)=v0(x,β,t)+zψβ(x,β,t),w(x,β,z,t)=w0(x,β,t), where -h/2≤z≤h/2 and h is the shell thickness; u0, v0, and w0 are midsurface displacements of the shell; and ψx and ψβ are midsurface rotations. The strain-displacement relationships in the principal coordinates of a cylindrical shell can be simplified from relevant equations for the general shell (Qatu, 2004) as (3)ɛx=∂u∂x, ɛβ=11+z/R(∂v∂β+wR), ɛz=∂w∂z,γxβ=11+z/R∂u∂β+∂v∂x, γxz=∂w∂x+∂u∂z,γβz=11+z/R∂w∂β+(1+z/R)∂∂z(v1+z/R). By substituting equations (2) into (3), strain-displacement equations become (4)ɛx=∂u0∂x+z∂ψx∂x,ɛβ=11+z/R(∂v0∂β+w0R+z∂ψβ∂β), ɛz=0,ɛxβ=∂v0∂x+z∂ψβ∂x, ɛβx=1(1+z/R)(∂u0∂β+z∂ψx∂β),γxz=∂w0∂x+ψx, γβz=11+z/R(∂w0∂β+ψβ-v0R). Figure 1.
Schematic view of a cylindrical shell.

The stress resultants are defined as (5)[Nx Nxβ Qx Mx Mxβ]T =∫-h/2h/2[σx σxβ σxz zσx zσxβ]T(1+zR)dz,[Nβ Nβx Qβ Mβ Mβx]T =∫-h/2h/2[σβ σβx σβz zσβ zσβx]Tdz, where the superscript T stands for the transpose of a vector. The applied load per unit area on the middle surface of the shell is q¯=qxe¯x+qβe¯β+qze¯z, where the unit vectors e¯x and e¯β are tangent to the principal axes and e¯z is the unit vector perpendicular to the shell surface. Let σ0x,σ0xβ and σ0xz be the components of applied traction on the edges x = constant and σ0β,σ0βx and σ0βz be the components of applied traction on the edges β = constant. The external work done by the external loads on the shell yields (6)δwext=∫t0t1{∫x∫β(qxδu+qβδv+qzδw)ABdxdβ+∫β∫-h/2h/2(σ0xδu+σ0xβδν+σ0xzδw)(1+z/R)dzdβ+∫x∫-h/2h/2(σ0βδv+σ0βxδu+σ0βzδw)dzdx}dt.

Substituting equations (5) into equation (6), the resultant equation with equations (4) into equation (1), employing the definitions (5), setting σz=0, and carrying out the required manipulations results in the following five equations of motion (7)∂Nx∂x+∂Nβx∂β+qx=I¯1u··0+I¯2ψ··x,∂Nβ∂β+∂Nxβ∂x+QβR+qβ=I¯1v··0+I¯2ψ··β,∂Qx∂x+∂Qβ∂β-NβR+qz=I¯1w··0, ∂Mx∂x+∂Mβx∂β-Qx=I¯2u··0+I¯3ψ··x,∂Mβ∂β+∂Mxβ∂x-Qβ=I¯2v··0+I¯3ψ··β, where (8)I¯i=(Ii+Ii+1R),i=1,2,3,[I1,I2,I3,I4]T=∑k=1N∫hk-1hkρ(k)[1,z,z2,z3]Tdz.
The boundary data on an edge x = constant are (9)either N0x-Nx=0 or u0=known,either N0xβ-Nxβ=0 or v0=known,either Q0x-Qx=0 or w0=known,either M0x-Mx=0 or ψx=known,either M0xβ-Mxβ=0 or ψβ=known.

The boundary conditions on an edge β=constant can be found by replacing x and u0 to β and v0, respectively, and vise versa in equations (9). Depending upon the type of the shell boundary, five boundary conditions should be chosen from the above cases at each edge. Therefore, there are 32 possible types of boundary conditions at each edge. Amongst those possible boundary conditions, a simply supported edge, S, clamped edge, C, and free edge, F, boundary conditions are selected in this work. Theses boundary conditions at the edge x = constant can be expressed as (10)S: Nx=v0=w0=Mx=ψβ=0,C: u0=v0=w0=ψβ=ψα=0,F: Nx=Nxβ=Qx=Mx=Mxβ=0.

Equations (4) are substituted into equations (11) the resultant equations into equations (5), carry out the integration in the thickness direction for a cylindrical shell composed of M layers while ignoring terms of O(z/R)2 and arrive at the following relationships for the stress resultants (12)[NxNβNxβNβxMxMβMxβMβx]=[A¯11A12A¯16A16B¯11B12B¯16B16A12A∧22A26A∧26B12B∧22B26B∧26A¯16A26A¯66A66B¯16B26B¯66B66A16A∧26A66A∧66B16B∧26B66B∧66B¯11B12B¯16B16D¯11D12D¯16D16B12B∧22B26B∧26D12D∧22D26D∧26B¯16B26B¯66B66D¯16D26D¯66D66B16B∧26B66B∧66D16D∧26D66D∧66] [∂u0/∂x∂v0/∂β+w0/R∂v0/∂x∂u0/∂β∂ψx/∂x∂ψβ/∂β∂ψβ/∂x∂ψx/∂β],[QxQβ]=[A¯55A45A45A∧44][∂w0/∂x+ψx∂w0/∂β+ψβ-v0/R] A¯ij=Aij-c0Bij,A∧ij=Aij+c0BijB¯ij=Bij-c0Dij,B∧ij=Bij+c0DijD¯ij=Dij-c0Eij,D∧ij=Dij+c0Eij}, i,j=1,2,4,5,6, where c0=-1/R and (13)Aij=∑k=1NQ¯ij(k)(hk-hk-1)Bij=12∑k=1NQ¯ij(k)(hk2-hk-12)Dij=13∑k=1NQ¯ij(k)(hk3-hk-13)Eij=14∑k=1NQ¯ij(k)(hk4-hk-14)} i,j=1,2,6,Aij=∑k=1NKxKβQ¯ij(k)(hk-hk-1), i,j=4,5,

hk-hk-1 is the thickness of the k-th layer, and Kx and Kβ are correction factors in x and β directions, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the presence of the components of A¯B¯D¯ and A∧B∧D∧ with ABD matrixes in equation (12) is the difference of the present theory (FSDTQ) by FSDT. The relevant equations for FSDT may be found by letting c0=0; thus, Λ¯ij=Λ∧ij=Λij where i,j=1,2,4,5,6 and Λ=A,B,D.

In order to investigate the bending of shells numerically, equations (4) should be substituted into (12). The resultants are put with equations (7) and arrive to the system of 15 first-order differential equations instead ofsubstituting the resultant into equations (7) and arriving to a system of five second-order differential equations. The system of 15 first-order differential equation is (14){[K]+[M]∂2∂t2}X¯=q¯, where X¯=[u0,v0,w0,ψx,ψβ,Nx,Nβ,Nxβ,Nβx,Mx,Mβ,Mxβ,Mβx,Qx,Qβ]T, components of square matrixes K and M are given in the Appendix and q¯1=qx,q¯2=qβ,q¯3=qz are the non-zero components of q¯. It should be emphasized that the presence of all the components of displacement and stress resultants in the system of equations (14), facilitates the direct application of all kinds of boundary conditions in the ensuing numerical treatment. The system of equations (14) is the equations of motion of the cylindrical shell. Letting q¯=0 and substituting X¯(t)=X¯1eiωt in the equation (14) lead to (15)[K-ω2M]X¯1=0, which is the relevant eigenvalue problem to find natural frequencies of the shell. The numerical solution of equations (15) may be accomplished by means of the GDQ method. The method is utilized by several investigators; see for instance (Asadi and Fariborz, 2011). In the GDQ method the derivative of a function at any discrete point in a direction is approximated as a weighted linear sum of the function values at all the sampling points in that direction (16)dF(xk)dx=∑l=1NCklF(xl),k∈{1,2,…,N} where N is the number of sampling points selected in the x-direction and Ckl are the weighting coefficients ofthe first derivative with respect to variable x and (17)Ckl=M(xk)(xk-xl)M(xl), k,l=1,2,…,N, k≠lCkk=-∑l=1l≠kNCkl, k=1,2,…,N, where M(xk)=Πl=1l≠kN(xk-xl).

The sampling points are chosen in the form of cosine distribution as (18)xk=Lx2[1-cos(k-1N-1π)], k=1,2,…,N where Lx is the length in x-direction. Application of equations (16) with respect to variables x and β to system of equations (15) in conjunction with boundary conditions (10) leads to a system of algebraic equations for displacements and stress resultants at the sampling points.

sec.title: 3. Results
sec.p: For all numerical analyses in this section the following are used unless otherwise mentioned. Laminated cylindrical shells with the length-to-arc ratio, a/b=1, thickness ratio, a/h=10 (moderately thick), depth ratio, a/R=2(very deep) and equal shear correction factors in both directions, k2=5/6 are considered. Also, the material properties for orthotropic materials are considered as E1/E2=25, G12/E2=0.5, G23/E2=0.2,G13=G12, and ν12=0.25. The first five natural frequency parameters Ωi=ωia2ρ/E2h2,i=1,…,5 with relevant mode shapes are calculated based on both FSDT and FSDTQ.

The convergence of the presented numerical method is studied with the increment of GDQ grid points in Table 1. An isotropic shell with a fully simply supported boundary condition (shear diaphragm) where the exact solution exists and reported by Asadi et al. (2012) is considered. The first natural frequency parameter converges with seven sampling points which is very fast; however, 11 sampling points are required for the convergence of other four natural frequencies. Table 1.
Convergence study of first five natural frequency parameters for an isotropic cylindrical shell
GDQ points Ω1 Ω2 Ω3 Ω4 Ω5
5×5 9.5816 14.3482 19.8219 21.5114 21.6487
7×7 9.5961 12.3892 19.6689 21.3934 22.7221
9×9 9.5961 12.3817 19.6609 21.3792 23.9669
11×11 9.5961 12.3813 19.6604 21.3784 23.9857
Exact (Asadi et al., 2012) 9.5961 12.381 19.660 21.378 23.986
GDQ: General Differential Quadrature.

Exact integration of equations (12) to calculate the component of A¯B¯D¯ and A∧B∧D∧ instead of approximating them was also proposed by Qatu (1995, 1999) and used by others to analyze different shells, e.g. Khdeir (2011). Table 2 compares the fundamental frequency parameter, ω¯=ωaρ/E2, obtained by Khdeir (2011) and presented FSDTQ with those 3D results of Ye and Soldatos (1994) for a [0/90] cylindrical panel with different depth ratios. The results show the maximum difference of 0.04% between presented results and those of calculated by Khdeir (2011) using the exact integration of equation (12) when comparing both of them with 3D results; thus, truncated terms in equation (12) are used in this study. FSDTQ: First-order Shear Deformation Shell Theory by Qatu.

For the rest of the numerical examples, orthotropic cylindrical shells with three different lay-ups and six different types of boundary conditions are considered, Figure 2, which are combinations of clamped, free andsimply supported boundary conditions. Presented results from both FSDT and FSDTQ are compared against each others and against those obtained using 3D elasticity from the finite element method (FEM). Figure 3 shows the mesh pattern of a typical cylindricalshell modeled using FEM wherein 3D elements are used. For simply supported boundary condition atα-constant, W and V are set to zero at the relevant plane of the boundary condition to make sure that v0=w0=ψβ=0 in presented theories. Also, all three displacements of the plane at the boundary edge are set to zero and free in the 3D finite element analyses for clamped and free boundary conditions; respectively. Moreover; the number of quadratic solid elements used in FEM did not exceed 40×40×12for the convergence of the results. Table 3 and Figure 4 show the first five natural frequency parameters and mode shapes, respectively; for a [0/90]3 cylindrical shell for the six types of boundary conditions. In all types of boundary conditions, natural frequency parameters predicted by 3D are the lowest and FSDTQ gives lower natural frequency parameters than those of FSDT and closer to 3D results. However, all three theories predict the same mode shapes. Tables 4 and 5 show the same results as in the previous table but for angle-ply [-45/45]3 and general [30/60/45] lay-ups; respectively. Also, the mode shapes for angle-ply and general lay-ups cylindrical shells are depicted in Figures 5 and 6; respectively. The same order in the calculated natural frequency parameters found in Table 3 is closely observed for the results in Tables 4 and 5. Also, both shear deformation theories give the same mode shapes as 3D results. It is worth mentioning that the difference between FSDT and FSDTQ and the difference between both of them and 3D results increase asthe number of natural frequency increases in all three sets of results. Moreover, the biggest difference in the results of shear deformation theories occurs in the second natural frequency parameter for FCFS boundary condition and the angle-ply lay-up wherein FSDTQ predicts a natural frequency 5.6% better than FSDT when comparing both to 3D results. sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: The equations of motion with required boundary conditions are obtained for composite cylindrical shells based on FSDTQ and FSDT. These equations of motion with stress resultants equations are put together to arrive at 15 first-order differential equations to free the vibration problem. These equations are solved numerically for different types of boundary conditions and lay-ups by means of the GDQ method. The FSDTQ offers a more accurate representation of the stiffness parameters and the stress resultant equations by including the 1 + z/R in the equations. Almost all analyses show that there is a significant improvement (closer to 3D) obtained when FSDTQ is used. This improvement increases when angle-ply or generally laminated composites are used for shells. Also, it varies with the change of boundary conditions. This analysis is a prelude to the derivation of a proper higher order shell theory (e.g. third order) where the term (1 + z/R) needs to be truncated at the third order.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
